Posts.Content: CONGRATULATIONS!!!!!!!! You made it through the FEC and the T and all the horrors that went with it. I know exactly what you mean about washing the hospital off. Yes. I am half dog half eagle. Not a pretty sight but I do try, and I have started wearing eyeshadow again, drawing those eyebrows back on. I know youve got the last side effects to get through, but enjoy being over the chemo, hope the nice weather continues, so you can ignore the housework and get out and about and sit amongst the daffodils. Posts.Content: Hi Suzie, ive been trying to find this thread for ages, I thought I'd lost you! Posts.Content: Hi Suzie and Susan, I'm into week 2 post Taxotere and I have about 2cms of the most BIZARRE hair sprouting out of my head. Posts.Title: Finished treatment today

Posts.Content: Hi Flower,  I had the same experience as you, I had been told I had a large area of DCIS with some invasive ductal carcinoma, after the Mastectomy I found I had 2 tumours, one 60mm and one12mm. The node biopsy came back positive 2 out of 3. I have now had an axillary clearance- no further nodes involved- and 5 of my 6 chemotherapy cycles. I have to have radiotherapy after chemo complete. The histology report was like a punch in the guts. I couldn't believe how different from the initial diagnosis it could be,I realised that harsh as it seemed, the goalposts had been shifted right across the park and I really had to face up to a much harder battle against this thing.  I hit rock bottom when they arranged for CT and Bone Scans, because I imagined it would have spread everywhere,  and I would have had more bad news to cope with. I cried and begged God or Buddha or angels or Ganesh or whoever was listening to give me more time with my kids. Half an hour before I went to theatre for the node clearance I was told both scans were clear. And after that, The fight back started. Ive struggled through the chemo- needed a Hickman line, been admitted to hospital twice with neutropenic sepsis, suffered agonising pain with docetaxel- and i'm not looking forward to the radiotherapy- 80 mile round trip. I'm tired and half mad most of the time but my strength comes from wanting to be with my family for a long time. You will find your strength too, and it will come suddenly when you realise what youve been through and survived, recovered from surgery, got through chemo,  heard the terrifying words of surgeons, when what they say is about you, some days making the tea has to be your fantastic achievement of the day, other days you'll feel you can take on anything or anyone. I wish you luck, and stay on the site. Reading others' posts and experiences has really helped when you feel youre going it alone. We're on this rollercoaster of crap. Your life has been turned upside down, but you're among friends, wishing you a good recovery from your next surgery, and good luck with your treatment. You'll find that strength, and you can do whatever you have to, be safe and go well, Trish
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, thinking of you! Good luck for Friday!! I'm having the usual fun after taxotere, with added abdominal distention just for fun.( I look pregnant with quads) I had bruising after my core biopsy. the radiologist did a really good local anaesthetic, so the core biopsy just felt like a bit of shoving, and the fine needle biopsy of the lymph nodes was the same, but 2 or 3 days after I came out black and blue and quite sore, and the bruises weren't where I'd expected them- ie where the needle things went in. The lump then got sore, and so did my arm down as far as the elbow. Ive just been reading a cracking good thread about what to take into hospital with you. Some excellent ideas. Good that youve got your nighties sorted out. V. important to have comfortable nighties. My main problem was the noise at night, cos the wards were always quite busy and bright, so I found the i-pod very helpful,with a good book downloaded onto it. i took lots of books for during the day, but when you want to go to sleep you need a nice boring story read with a droning voice! Just take care of yourself. Also Snacks! In the hospital i was in, you get your tea at 5pm and then nothing til breakfast at 8 the next morning.Shocking. I'm a night time nibbler so I had to get supplies in. They'll probably give you regular painkillers, and youll want something on your stomach. Rads start on the 11th of April. 15 sessions. Shriek! Its really good to be able to count the weeks til the end of the big treatments, but Ive got the scan first, so fingers crossed it'll be good news. You'll be great, make sure y0u rest and take good care of yourself Best best best luck and hugs ((( ))) Trish x
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, Its horrible waiting isn't it? I'm ok after the surgery thanks, and its really strange but the thought of having a big fat elephant arm has upset me more than losing a breast, chemotherapy, losing hair and eyelashes. i had the mastectomy first- I was offered immediate reconstruction but chose not to have it and woke up with a nice neat scar which extended about 3 cms under the arm. I had an infusion pump with local anaesthetic into the wound for 3 days post op and never felt a thing. I went home with suction drains in and the district nurses came and measured the gloop every day. When they went back for the axillary nodes, they went through the same scar, and I had IV morphine and it was quite sore.I felt a lot of pain in my shoulder. I was a lazy troll and didnt do my exercises as often as I should so I got cording which took about 2 weeks  with massage and stretching to get rid of. I'm really fastidious about the exercises now.I went home the next day  with 2 vacuum drains again, which oozed away for a week before removed. I think I lost a lot of blood with the 2 procedures and the drain - which is something to think about if you do end up having chemo- if your Hb drops below 10 you may have to have a blood transfusion.( if youre a meat eater get some steak and mince- spinach didn't cut it for me) I didn't know I needed radiotherapy til after I got the histology results. If I'd had the implant, they said it would just need deflating and wouldn't be a problem. My arm was numb to the elbow, and round the wound was patchy (feeling not appearance). Sensation has started to come back, but as I'm still numb from a cesarian section 10 years ago I'm not sure how much will return. Watch out for the cording, its nasty. After the drains were removed my arm seemed to get puffy, and i did worry about lymphoedema. Nicola my BCN showed me how to massage the arm, and in the evening I used to sit with my arm raised on cushions - above heart level- for the fluid to drain away. I also use Kinesio (?) tape to stop the scar getting tethered and to help lymph drainage. Make sure you have some nice strong pain killers to hand - you might not need them, but its good to know theyre there. Really really wishing you good luck for the op. try and have a bit of a rest if you can before they chuck you out. I got a nice planner from the physios telling me what I should and should not be doing in terms of housework- first fortnight NOTHING next week make a cup of tea sort of thing. Presented to husband with instructions to crack on with the washing etc. Wishing you well, fingers crossed that you wont need chemo/rads and the other nasties. Do you know if you'll need herceptin or tamoxifen yet? Good luck and very best wishes (don't know if any of that helps but here's a hug (( )). It'll be ok.) Trish

Posts.Content: Hello lesleym44, I'm so sorry to hear you've lost your good friend and you must feel pretty raw at this time. I'm glad you're fighting hard and we will get through it. Sometimes it seems as though fate waits until we are at the limit of endurance before dealing out another slap. I'm not having Herceptin but I've had my third cycle of FEC and am suffering with hot flushes and night sweats. The nights are miserable with me burning up, shoving the covers off, freezing, dragging up the covers, boiling,,etc. the lack of sleep is making me slightly mad.I've been trying to find some solutions , and have read that for symptoms of menopause, so far:- Black Cohosh, lots of Soya,sage tincture, chasteberry, avoid alcohol,coffee, hot drinks,and spicy food, Try vitamin E and best of all, a tepid bath for 20 minutes every morning. I don't know if any/all of them are ok with your Herceptin. I've started drinking soya milk and having soya yoghurt but I seem to cancel that benefit by eating curry twice a day - I love Thai green curry and its one of the few things that taste normal to me. I'm going to try the black cohosh next and work my way through them til I find something that works. Good luck with the rest of the herceptin. You need some sad time, to grieve for a friend, but keep climbing the hill. Best wishes, Trish
